questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Corinthians 1:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'God of all comfort' in verse 3 and Paul's description of his burden in verses 8-9.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'comfort' in verses 3, 4, and 7
Pay attention to the contrast between Paul's burden and God's comfort in verses 8-9
Note the phrase 'we share abundantly in Christ's sufferings' in verse 5

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Paul and the Corinthians) is involved, WHAT (God comforts us in affliction), WHERE (the church in Corinth and the spiritual realm), and WHY (to share in Christ's comfort and salvation).
tips: Include Paul's personal experience of being burdened (verse 8-9)
Note that the comfort comes from God who is the Father of mercies and God of all comfort (verse 3)
Describe the connection between our afflictions and the comfort for others (verse 7)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the phrase 'God of all comfort' (v.3), Paul's burden and deliverance (v.8-9), or the sharing in Christ's sufferings (v.5).
tips: The phrase 'God of all comfort' in verse 3 is a powerful declaration of God's nature
Paul's description of his own burden and how God delivered him (v.8-9) shows the depth of his need
The idea that our affliction is for the comfort of others (v.7) is a profound connection

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth about God's comfort in their afflictions?
tips: Paul is emphasizing that God's comfort in our sufferings enables us to comfort others
He is showing that his own experience of suffering and deliverance by God is a model for the Corinthians
The main point is that God's comfort is not just for us but for the purpose of comforting others through Christ

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? Paul's description of his burden, the concept of sharing in Christ's sufferings, and the phrase 'God of all comfort'.
tips: Paul's burden (verse 8-9) is a deep spiritual experience that may be hard to relate to today
Sharing in Christ's sufferings (verse 5) requires understanding that our suffering is part of the Christian life and connected to Christ's sacrifice
The phrase 'God of all comfort' (verse 3) might be misunderstood as God only comforting when we are in trouble, but Paul emphasizes God comforts us in all affliction

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's comfort in your current affliction this week?
tips: Identify one area where you are experiencing affliction and pray for God's comfort
Ask God to help you share that comfort with someone else who is suffering
Practice being a comforter by listening and being present, as Paul encourages

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being the God of all comfort and ask for His comfort in your afflictions.
tips: Thank God for comforting you in your current struggles
Pray for the courage to share God's comfort with others who are suffering
Ask God to help you trust Him in your afflictions, just as Paul did

chapters.chapterTitle: Forgiveness and the Fragrance of Christ

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Corinthians 2:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone and the repetition of 'forgiveness' and 'fragrance'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'if anyone has caused pain' (v.6-7)
Pay attention to the phrase 'the fragrance of Christ' (v.14-15)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being addressed (the church in Corinth), WHAT Paul is doing (writing to prevent pain and encourage forgiveness), WHERE it takes place (the church in Corinth and Paul's travels), and WHY he is writing (to avoid causing more pain and to reaffirm love so they are not outwitted by Satan).
tips: Include Paul's decision not to visit (v.1-4)
Note the call to forgive the offender (v.6-7)
Mention the triumphal procession (v.14-13)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the call to forgive (v.6-7), the fragrance of Christ (v.15), or the triumphal procession (v.14)?
tips: The call to forgive emphasizes that the church's unity is vital for the offender's restoration
The fragrance of Christ is a powerful metaphor for how the church's life in Christ can be life-giving or death-inducing
The triumphal procession shows God's active leadership in the church's mission

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth through this passage?
tips: Paul wants the church to forgive and comfort the offender to maintain unity and prevent Satan from taking advantage
The church's role as the aroma of Christ is central to the gospel mission
This passage shows that forgiveness is a sign of the church's participation in Christ's triumphal procession

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'not outwitted by Satan', the fragrance of Christ, and the triumphal procession?
tips: 'Not outwitted by Satan' means the church must forgive to prevent Satan from using the offense to cause more harm
The fragrance of Christ is a metaphor for how the church's life in Christ can bring life or death to others
The triumphal procession is a symbol of God's victory and the church's role in spreading the gospel

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: As the church, how can you apply the call to forgive and comfort the offender in your own community this week?
tips: Identify someone who has caused pain and offer forgiveness and comfort
Pray for the offender to be restored and the church to be united
Practice active listening and empathy when someone has hurt you

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of forgiveness and the fragrance of Christ.
tips: Thank God for His grace that allows us to forgive and comfort others
Ask for the strength to be the fragrance of Christ that brings life to others
Pray for the church to not be outwitted by Satan through forgiveness

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Cor 3:1-18 aloud, focusing on the contrast between the old covenant (letters on stone) and the new covenant (the Spirit working on hearts).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'letter' and 'Spirit' (v.3, v.6)
Pay attention to the phrase 'we are ministers of a new covenant' (v.6)
Listen for the emotional shift from the 'ministry of death' to the 'ministry of life' (v.4-5)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe who (Paul and the Corinthians), what (the new covenant ministry), where (in the church in Corinth), and why (to overcome the old covenant's limitations).
tips: Paul's letter of recommendation to the Corinthians (v.1)
The contrast between the old covenant (letters on stone) and new covenant (Spirit on hearts) (v.3-4)
The transformation of believers into Christ's image (v.18)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Which part of 2 Cor 3 stands out? Consider: the letter kills vs. Spirit gives life (v.3-4), the veil being removed (v.16), or the transformation into Christ's image (v.18).
tips: The phrase 'the veil is removed' (v.16) - it's a powerful image of how Christ's presence removes barriers
The transformation from one degree of glory to another (v.18) - it's a promise of ongoing growth
The contrast between the ministry of death (v.7) and the ministry of the Spirit (v.6)

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth about their identity as ministers of the new covenant?
tips: Paul is emphasizing that their identity comes from God, not their own efforts (v.5)
He wants them to see that the new covenant is active in their lives through the Spirit, not the old covenant's law
This passage addresses their current struggles with legalism and points to the Spirit's work

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of 2 Cor 3 are challenging? The meaning of 'ministry of death' and 'ministry of the Spirit'? The role of the veil? The transformation into Christ's image?
tips: 'Ministry of death' (v.7) refers to the old covenant's law that could not bring life, not a literal death
The 'veil' (v.16) is a metaphor for the barrier of sin and law that is removed by Christ's presence
'Transformed into the same image' (v.18) means becoming more like Christ progressively, not a one-time event

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be a minister of the new covenant this week by living in the Spirit, not the law?
tips: Practice daily surrender to the Spirit's guidance rather than legalistic rules
Identify one area where you feel the 'veil' (barrier) and pray for Christ to remove it
Share the new covenant hope with someone who is struggling with the old covenant (law)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about being transformed into Christ's image and becoming a minister of the new covenant.
tips: Thank God for the new covenant and the Spirit's work in your life
Ask for the courage to remove the veil of sin and fear in your life
Pray for the church in Corinth (and us) to be transformed into Christ's image by the Spirit

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Corinthians 7:1-16 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between godly grief and worldly grief in verses 10-16.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'grief' (v. 8-10) and 'repentance' (v. 15)
Pay attention to the phrase 'without regret' (v. 16) as a key emotional tone
The contrast between 'godly grief' (v. 10) and 'worldly grief' (v. 16) is central

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Paul and the Corinthian church) does WHAT (experiences grief and repents) WHERE (in the church in Corinth) and WHY (to produce salvation without regret).
tips: Include Paul's letter that grieved the Corinthians (v. 13)
Note the role of Titus in bringing comfort (v. 11)
Highlight the result: godly grief leading to repentance (v. 15)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the contrast between godly and worldly grief (v. 16), the earnestness of the Corinthians' grief (v. 17), or Paul's joy in their repentance (v. 15)?
tips: The phrase 'Godly grief produces a repentance that leads to salvation without regret' (v. 16) is the core theological statement
The list of emotions in v. 17 (earnestness, eagerness, indignation, etc.) shows the depth of their transformation
Paul's joy in their repentance (v. 15) is a powerful contrast to the initial grief

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth through this passage?
tips: Paul is clarifying that the Corinthians' grief (over his letter) was godly and led to repentance, which is the opposite of worldly grief that leads to death
This passage emphasizes that true repentance is a response to God's grace and results in salvation without regret, not because of punishment but because of God's comfort
Paul's purpose is to encourage the Corinthians to see the positive outcome of their grief and to avoid the danger of worldly grief

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The distinction between godly and worldly grief? Why Paul's letter grieved them? The role of Titus?
tips: In Hebrew, 'grief' (mishpachah) can have different connotations, but here Paul distinguishes between godly grief (which leads to repentance) and worldly grief (which leads to death)
The Corinthians had been grieved by Paul's letter (v. 13) but Paul says it was only temporary and led to repentance â€” this might be confusing because they were already in a state of sin
The term 'worldly grief' (v. 16) is a contrast that might be hard to grasp in modern contexts where grief is often seen as universal

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the concept of godly grief producing repentance in your life this week?
tips: Identify a situation where you are experiencing grief (like disappointment or failure) and ask: Is this godly grief (leading to repentance) or worldly grief (leading to death)?
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you discern the type of grief you are experiencing and to lead you to repentance
Take one step to repent in a specific area (e.g., sin, pattern of behavior) this week, knowing that godly grief leads to salvation without regret

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about this chapter's theme: Godly grief producing repentance and salvation without regret.
tips: Thank God that His grief (when it comes from the Holy Spirit) produces repentance and leads to salvation
Ask for the courage to experience godly grief when you are tempted by sin
Pray that the Corinthians' example (v. 17) inspires you to have earnestness and zeal for God's truth

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Corinthians 8:1-15 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'the grace of God' and the contrast between 'poverty' and 'abundance'.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'for the grace of God' (v. 2, 4, 7)
Pay attention to the contrast in verses 3 and 4: 'in poverty, they give generously'
The phrase 'of their own accord, begging earnestly' (v. 4) shows their voluntary nature

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the Macedonian churches) does WHAT (gives generously), WHERE (the church in Corinth), and WHY (to show their love for the saints and to follow Christ's example of becoming rich through poverty).
tips: The Macedonian churches were in severe affliction (v. 1-2)
Paul emphasizes that they gave beyond their means (v. 4-5)
The purpose was to relieve the saints in need (v. 3-4)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the Macedonian churches' generosity (v. 3-4), Paul's description of Christ becoming poor (v. 9), or the call to 'excel in this act of grace' (v. 12).
tips: The phrase 'the grace of God' (v. 2) is foundational and shows God's initiative
Paul's description of Christ becoming poor (v. 9) is a powerful theological anchor for generosity
The command 'excel in this act of grace' (v. 12) is a call to both action and attitude

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth through this passage?
tips: Paul wants the Corinthians to recognize the grace of giving that the Macedonians demonstrated, which is modeled by Christ's poverty
He is challenging them to move beyond mere words to active generosity that reflects their love for Christ
The main point is that true generosity is a response to God's grace and follows Christ's example of self-giving

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'abundance in poverty', the meaning of 'Christ became poor', or the practical application of giving beyond one's means?
tips: The phrase 'abundance in poverty' (v. 3) refers to the spiritual richness that comes from God's grace despite material lack
Christ becoming poor (v. 9) is a theological concept that describes Christ's humility and self-giving on the cross
Giving beyond one's means (v. 4) requires a spiritual understanding that generosity is not about wealth but about heart condition

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'generosity in poverty' this week? Specifically, what situation requires you to give beyond your means?
tips: Consider a practical way to give to a cause that aligns with your current financial situation
Reflect on how your generosity might be an act of love for others as Christ did
Start with a small but intentional giving that shows your heart's condition

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His grace in giving and ask for the courage to give generously.
tips: Thank God for the example of the Macedonians and for His grace that enables us to give
Pray for the strength to give beyond our means when it is costly
Ask God to help us see the abundance in poverty and to follow Christ's example

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Corinthians 9:1-15 aloud, focusing on the contrast between 'sowing sparingly' and 'sowing bountifully' in verses 10-11.
tips: Note the repetition of 'cheerful' in verses 12-13
Pay attention to the phrase 'God loves a cheerful giver' (v.13) which is the climax
The phrase 'sow bountifully, reap bountifully' (v.10) is the core principle

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being urged to give, WHAT they are to do, WHERE this giving is happening, and WHY Paul emphasizes cheerful giving.
tips: Include Paul's reference to the Corinthians' readiness (v.1-2)
Note the contrast between the Corinthians' boasting and the need for their readiness (v.3-5)
Describe the promise that God will provide for their generosity (v.10-11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the Corinthians' boasting (v.3), the principle of 'sow bountifully, reap bountifully' (v.10), or God's promise to supply (v.14).
tips: The phrase 'sow bountifully, reap bountifully' (v.10) is a powerful promise that challenges the Corinthians' previous boasting
The image of God supplying 'seed and bread' (v.10) shows His active role in generosity
The contrast between 'cheerful' and 'reluctant' giving (v.13) highlights the heart condition

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth about the nature of generous giving?
tips: Paul is addressing the Corinthians' boasting about their readiness to give (v.3) and ensuring it is genuine and not empty
The main point is that true generosity comes from a joyful heart, not obligation, and God will abundantly supply those who give cheerfully
This passage connects to the broader theme of Christ's gift (v.13) and the Corinthians' role in the church

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The definition of 'cheerful' giving, the promise of God's provision, or the contrast with the Corinthians' past behavior?
tips: The term 'cheerful' (v.13) is not about the amount but the heart condition - it's a response to God's love, not a legal requirement
The promise of God providing for their needs (v.10) might seem odd because the Corinthians were the ones being given to (v.1-2), so it's about God's grace enabling generosity
The phrase 'sow bountifully, reap bountifully' (v.10) is a principle that requires understanding that generosity is a result of God's work in the giver, not a transaction

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice cheerful giving this week by giving as you have decided in your heart (v.13)?
tips: Identify one area where you might be giving reluctantly (e.g., tithing, volunteering) and ask God to make it cheerful
Reflect on what you have already decided to give (v.13) and how you can do it without compulsion
Pray for God to supply your needs so you can be generous (v.10-11) without fear

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His inexpressible gift (Christ) and ask for a cheerful heart to give generously.
tips: Thank God for providing Christ as the ultimate gift (v.13) and how He enables us to give
Pray for courage to give cheerfully when it's difficult (e.g., financially, time)
Ask God to help you understand that your generosity is a response to His grace, not a burden

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Corinthians 11:1-15 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between Paul's humility and the false apostles.
tips: Notice the phrase 'betrothed them to one husband' (v.2) emphasizes the church's sacred relationship with Christ
Pay attention to the description of false apostles as 'deceitful workmen' (v.13) who disguise themselves as apostles of Christ
Notice Paul's repeated emphasis on his sufferings and weaknesses (v.10-11) as a sign of his commitment

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being warned (Paul), WHAT is being warned against (false apostles), WHERE this occurs (the church in Corinth), and WHY (to protect the church from deception).
tips: Include Paul's protective jealousy for the church (v.2)
Note the false apostles' claim to be apostles but being deceitful (v.13-15)
Describe Paul's boasting in his sufferings and weaknesses (v.10-11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Paul's description of the church as a 'pure virgin' (v.2), the false apostles' deception (v.13-15), or Paul's boasting in weaknesses (v.10-11)?
tips: Paul's use of the marriage metaphor (betrothed to Christ) shows the church's unique relationship with Christ
The false apostles are described as 'deceitful workmen' who disguise themselves as apostles of Christ (v.13) - this is a powerful image of deception
Paul's willingness to boast in his sufferings (beatings, imprisonments) as a sign of his commitment (v.10-11) is a testament to his faithfulness

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth about the danger of false apostles and the importance of true faith?
tips: Paul wants the church to recognize that false apostles are a threat to their unity and truth
True apostleship is marked by suffering and humility, not by boasting in power
The church must be vigilant to avoid being led astray by false teachers

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'betrothed' in a marital sense, the comparison of false apostles to Satan, or the meaning of 'boast in weaknesses'?
tips: In ancient Greek, 'betrothed' (gamos) refers to a marriage covenant, not a literal marriage. Paul uses it to show the church is already in Christ's care
Satan disguises himself as an angel of light (v.14) - this is a common theme in the Bible but Paul applies it to false apostles
Boasting in weaknesses (v.10) is a way of showing humility and faithfulness, not weakness in the negative sense

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Paul boasts in his weaknesses. What area of your life requires you to trust God's provision, even when it's costly?
tips: Consider a situation where you are facing hardship and could be tempted to give up
How can you practice 'boasting in weaknesses' by sharing your struggles with God?
Think about a time when you had to endure suffering for a cause

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for protecting us from false teachers and ask for strength to live in faithfulness.
tips: Thank God for the truth that He is the only true God and that false apostles are deceptive
Pray for the church in Corinth to remain united in Christ
Ask God to help us recognize and resist false teachings

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Corinthians 12:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'thorn in the flesh' (v. 7-8) and the repeated emphasis on weakness.
tips: Note the phrase 'my grace is sufficient for you' (v. 9) repeated as a theme
Pay attention to the contrast between Paul's strength and his weakness (v. 9-10)
The emotional tone shifts from frustration to acceptance in the plea for the thorn to leave

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Paul) is boasting about, WHAT (his weaknesses), WHERE (in the flesh), and WHY (the thorn's purpose).
tips: Identify Paul's struggle with the thorn (v. 7-8)
Explain the thorn's role in his spiritual life (v. 1-4)
Connect the thorn to divine purpose (v. 9)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Select the verse that best captures the core message about spiritual trials and divine purpose.
tips: Focus on verse 9: 'my grace is sufficient for you'
Consider how this verse relates to modern spiritual challenges
Apply this principle to your own life context

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: How can the concept of 'sufficient grace' (v. 9) help you face current spiritual struggles?
tips: Identify one specific trial in your life
Reflect on how God's grace meets that trial
Pray for increased reliance on grace during that trial

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What does the 'thorn in the flesh' (v. 7-8) reveal about God's character and our relationship with Him?
tips: Examine the thorn as a sign of divine sovereignty (v. 7-8)
Consider how God uses trials to deepen our relationship
Connect to Christ's suffering (v. 9)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read 2 Corinthians 13:1-13 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between Paul's warnings and his hopeful benediction.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'examine yourselves' (v.2) and 'Christ is in you' (v.5)
Pay attention to the emotional shift from warning to prayer for restoration (v.7-8)
The phrase 'for we also are weak in Him, but in dealing with them we will live with Him by the power of God' (v.10) shows the hope

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO Paul is addressing, WHAT he warns about, WHERE this warning is happening, and WHY he is writing now (while absent).
tips: Include that Paul has been in Corinth twice before
Note that the church is under threat of being judged by Paul if he returns
Paul's goal is restoration, not destruction

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Paul's warning about coming again (v.3), the call to examine yourselves (v.2), or the trinitarian benediction (v.13)?
tips: The phrase 'Christ is in you' (v.5) is a powerful reminder of the believer's identity
The contrast between 'weakness' and 'power' in verse 10 shows the strength of Christ in believers
The benediction (v.13) with grace, love, and fellowship is a hopeful closing

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Corinth through this passage?
tips: Paul wants the Corinthians to be in the faith and to examine themselves so they don't face harsh correction
This passage shows that Christ is the source of strength and unity for the church
Paul's purpose is to encourage restoration and unity, not to condemn

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'examine yourselves' (v.2) in a modern context? Why Paul might not spare them if he returns? The meaning of 'Christ is in you' (v.5)?
tips: 'Examine yourselves' (v.2) is a call to self-assessment that may be difficult in a community setting
The phrase 'we also are weak in Him' (v.10) might be confusing as it contrasts with the strength of Christ
The trinitarian benediction (v.13) with grace, love, and fellowship is a unique way to close the letter

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Based on the call to examine yourselves (v.2), what specific step can you take this week to ensure you are in the faith?
tips: Write down one area where you feel you might be out of the faith and seek Christ's help
Ask a friend to help you examine your faith in a small group
Pray for the Holy Spirit to guide your self-examination

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He is with us in weakness and that He provides strength through Christ. Ask for the church to be restored and united.
tips: Thank God for the promise that Christ is in you (v.5)
Pray for courage to examine your faith and for the Holy Spirit to guide
Ask God to help the church in Corinth (and us) to live in peace and unity
